posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

Most Mario games 2000 and before that frequently have Mario doing weird things, going to weird places, and enemies that are off model. At some point going from the gamecube and into non retro consoles, things starting getting more and more uniform: Toads are often the only friendly characters, koopa troopas all look the same, and Mario often stays in more safe locations with the classic brick blocks and ? blocks.
Sure, there's some exceptions, but I cannot go into detail there because it's not retro. But generally Mario has gotten really sterile and safe, because Miyamoto feels like Mario has an image that can't be tarnished. Nintendo's Mickey Mouse.

>>9526440
Some time in the mid to late 2010s or whenever the fuck, a lot of character designs and whatnot of Mario characters started standardized, most notably Toads and certain enemies. While it's unclear if it is part of the mandate or just Nintendo being lazy/formulamatic, Mario games also followed a general theme structure that was rarely broken (grasslands first, desert second, beach third, etc).
The "Mario mandate" aspect mostly comes from the RPGs, primarily Paper Mario Sticker Star, where the team were told to not to make any new characters (Kersti being the lone exception). Some comments made around the time of Origami King's release suggest that this clause is still in affect in some way, with new characters needing to be very distinct. This standardization also carried on throughout other RPGs where the more distinct and out there Toad designs have been dropped, although NPC variety tends to be a slightly better due to using mooks/Yoshis as well as Toads.
Basically, all of this cemented Miyamoto as a control-freak mad man hellbent on removing the "soul" from the series. Whether or not he actually is in reality is up for debate.
>>9525240
They likely do, but wouldn't be relevant due to most Nintendo series being done in-house and having more consistency compared to the Mario games.

I'm pretty sure Dream Team came out after Sticker Star, since there were people misinterpreting the Iwata Asks to assume that Miyamoto tried meddling in that game and got rebuffed whereas the actual reality seems a bit more complicated (and didn't seem to involve Miyamoto himself).
https://iwataasks.nintendo.com/interviews/3ds/mario-and-luigi-dream-team/0/2/
In general, Sticker Star kinda caught everyone off-guard, so later RPGs were looked at more critically. Then it escalated into what we see now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9528286
I fucking love SMRPG Mario as a character and really wish we got more games with this take of the character.
As someone who never got into 3D platformers, this was the last Mario game I played to completion, and is still the mental image I have for Mario when I play the original NES/SNES games.
Silent protagonist, no voice clips, a "fish out of water" simple guy (but not in the "novice-incompetent" way of the new movie, someone with a fame and looked up to). Communicates through jumps and gestures. Not completly childish, still having some cheekyness (in SMRPG he has moments where he's angry, taunts throwing punches, acts jealous... attitudes I wouldn't picture modern Mario having)
Besides, look at him. Chunky, cute, funny, but rough enough to not give you the "not sure if innocent or retarded" vibe of the modern one. Looks like someone who can be strong. It's like a toy. Makes me want to play with him/as him.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9533263
A few reasons, but it seems to be a combination of Tanabe just not understanding RPG structure or gameplay and Tanabe taking Miyamoto's criticism of the original build too far. Heck, going by his comments in the Iwata Asks, Tanabe doesn't even consider Sticker Star (and by extension Color Splash at the very least) an RPG.
https://iwataasks.nintendo.com/interviews/3ds/papermario/0/2/
>That's right. At first, we were making a lot of individual allies as in a regular RPG, but when we decided to focus on stickers, in order to make a clear change with previous games in the series, it was like we started all over again by throwing out the system—including those characters—that we had made up to that point.
>Yes. We decided to make it so that players would face stronger opponents by throwing out the whole concept of experience points and levels in favor of gradually gathering stronger stickers.
>I had actually been thinking for a long time that I wanted to get rid of the RPG experience points. In the Freshly-Picked Tingle's Rosy Rupeeland28 game, which Kudo-san and I worked on together, the player-character didn't develop at all. We adopted a system whereby they solved everything with money.
>This time, we decided to do everything with stickers. We decided on a system whereby in battle, instead of attack commands, you fight by using the stickers you have gathered in the field or bought in town.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This is literally the worst designed boss in existence on hard difficulty.

There is no rhyme or reason or tells to any of his movements. His swaying is completely fucking random, when he decides to go in is completely fucking random, and how many attacks he does when he goes in is also totally fucking random. Not to mention his fake-outs are indecipherable from his attacks until the very last second, which combined with the massive hitbox and the fact that he oftentimes sways above/below you right before going in, you oftentimes will physically not have enough time to react, as you have to scale literally half the wall in a fraction of a second.

As someone who has played and mastered a lot of games, I could instantly tell within about a minute or two (after determining that there is no memo and it's all pure RNG bullshit) that this was a poorly designed shit boss from an incompetent hack; and usually Konami are pretty good, so I am very disappointed. Of course, I decide to check a no-miss hard run just to see how players tackled it. Of course, just as I thought and confirming my suspicions, literally the only way anyone ever deals with it is to use a bomb combined with the C-C weapon swap spam exploit. There is zero consistent method that doesn't involve the weapon swap spam exploit, and even that is likely not consistent every run due to the extreme RNG. Again, if he decides to sway towards your escape direction right before going in, you are FUCKED; there is no literally physical way you can escape in time, as even jumping literally does not give you enough time to escape.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You can learn to always keep yourself in a space where you can dodge, you just have to crawl up and down to trick him into hitting where you were.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9537317
That literally doesn't work. Sometimes he arbitrarily sways before going in to attack. So say you are at the top and going to dodge down, he will sway down before attacking and now you have a nanosecond to literally cover over half the wall (because both yours and his hitbox are massive).

I even tested with save states just to ensure that his behavior is completely independent of your movement, which it is (obviously he lazily tracks you, but whether he sways or not has nothing to do with any action of your own, and is purely random).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9537317
>>9537321
Also because the difference between his fakeout attacks and actual attacks is so minimal, you always have to move whenever he lunges, whether it's fake or real. What this means is that sometimes he can follow up a fakeout attack with a real double attack immediately, and then you are completely fucked, since the only way you can 100% dodge every time is if you are right on the very top or very bottom and start reacting as soon as he lunges (before you even know if it's fake or real). If you are anyway but the very top or bottom, and especially if he sways, then you just die if he goes for any attack, but especially a double.

>>9537293
the key difference from back then and now is that there was a clear divide between cutscene and gameplay, not this blending of the two where the game is constantly taking control away from the player to make it 'seamless', or forcing you to do slow walking sections, or """hidden loading""" screens by walking through small cracks in a wall. all these severely hamper future playthroughs thanks to all the stops.

in mgs1/2/3 you can just skip the cutscene and codec, and very rarely does the game stop you to show you the end goal mid gameplay, things like "a surveillance camera" cutscene in 1, or the "RAVEN!?" cutscene in 2 can be skipped right away. The game doesn't hand hold you constantly unless you call the codec and then they'll give you advice.
The gameplay also didn't take a hit because of it's story, like most cinematic games do now. There's a lot of replayability and experimentation in these games, specially 2 and 3 with all the fun tools it gives you to mess with the guards, most cinematics games are basic, and not there's not a lot of room for experimentation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Magazines and the average pleb saw it as the most amazing things and video games "maturing".

The thing is, people were even more insecure about the media back then. So when people were able to say "Look! It's like a movie!", for them it's a way to "prove" their media isn't childish toys for pre schoolers, it's also "just like that stuff you watch on TV all the time!"

Little did/do they people realize that "being like movies" is exactly what brings the media down. By imitating movies, video games are always a step behind. Some books or movies are able to create new trends, trends that others will copy and even transcend the media to reach other media. No video game has ever created such a trend exactly because they are too busy being this cool cinematic stuff that re-enacts the current trends.
Instead, video games could have been so much more, create their own story telling techniques that no other media could have, and yet we've barely scratched the surface of that potential. Because everyone is too busy trying to appear just like that cool movie people like so they can hand prices to each others like it was the Oscars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538827
3 has the worst gameplay and is imo the worst main MGS in general. A lot of systems that are convoluted seemingly for their own sake: the cure system with the RNG wounds that literally just waste your time healing (it's not even another difficulty layer since you just pause the game and nothing can happen to you), the camo menu, the awful CQC, the weight limits. The way MGS2 handles wounds is more effective (even though it's like something out of a cartoon) because it plays out in real time instead of a menu, healing supplies are scarce on higher difficulty levels, and the tighter maps combined with the faster guards means that leaving a trail of blood is actually a serious problem, besides being much better and more streamlined gameplay anyway, while you get stuck on trees and other shit in MGS3 all the time because the gameplay formula is designed around blocky, sterile rooms and not messy jungles. Not even sure why they fucked with the radar just because it would be "more realistic", as if a health bar would be realistic, but the only result is that you spend a lot more time waiting and looking at primitive 3D graphics.

The MGS2 alert system is completely unpolished in this game, which becomes especially apparent in the weapons lab, where it's always more time-efficient to just let soldiers kill you or reload your game instead of waiting for the alert and guards to fuck off, similar to the bad gameplay in games like The Evil Within, where you can run into traps and lose 99% your health right after a checkpoint. In older games, you could usually do something or the checkpoints were less forgiving.

The bosses feel even more like cinematic experiences than in previous games, one even letting you win by literally just waiting. Both friends and foes are uninteresting in comparison with 1 and especially 2, radio conversations just being .jpgs now and a generic super soldier with anime powers the main villain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9537293

At first more "cinematic" meant that the entire gaming industry is expanding what CAN be done within the medium and there was much hype for it.
The jump to CDs and later DVDs also allowed far more high production level content to be packed in and that opened up the potential.

But starting with MGS2 I think the line between "too much" was well defined. MGS2 in particular had a demo that everyone played into oblivion and when the actual game got released later and you got essentially a visual novel with a bit of gunplay people soured on it.
I think that was a moment where it became clear that too much of it meant there's not enough "game" in your game.
That's why MGS3 in particular tones it down and gives you far more gameplay to work with.

Later on (today's gaming era) the entire field got saturated by movie-producing wannabes that see the medium as a platform for their b-movie sensibilities and "storytelling" and it's again choking the medium. Luckily this time around you have a million indie games if you don't want AAA movie-games.

It just overwrites a bunch of values in memory. Basically most things like player health etc. are stored as variables in RAM. The gameshark overwrites the values to "fool" the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9533447
That article is blatantly wrong. The program was not made as a diss, and it was definitely not shown to any lawyers as an act of pettiness, it was just a silly private joke shown to a couple friends.

Here's David Crane's personal explanation of it:
>“The Venetian Blind cart is a working 2600 demo that shows a landscape at sunset outside a window, covered by a fully operational Venetian Blind — one that moves up and down under joystick control. Here is how it came about:
>When Atari sued Activision they laid claim to certain ‘proprietary’ techniques. One technique for which they claimed ownership was first used by Bob Whitehead in the display code of the Atari Chess cartridge. This method moved the display objects back and forth every scan line to allow the game to display more objects. On the chess pieces, for example, Bob showed the odd pixel row of the odd numbered columns of pieces and the even pixel row of the even numbered columns. We called this the Venetian Blind technique since it made the pieces look like they were being viewed through a venetian blind.
>One day in the lab at Activision while the lawsuit was in full swing, Bob and I collaborated on a practical joke. We made a display showing an architecturally accurate window with a view of a grassy hill at sunset. We covered it with a venetian blind effect that animated up and down (complete with the stacking up of the slats as they were gathered up by the blind mechanism). We took it to CES and showed it to a few people who were privy to the lawsuit, asking ‘Is this what Atari means by the Venetian Blind Technique?’
>The joke was on us in one respect, when we realized that we had made public our latest innovation (the background sunset) when we showed it to our competitors. (Several games in the lab were using this new idea, but they had not yet been published.) As it turned out, nobody picked up on our slip and nobody beat us to market with the sunset.” ~ David Crane

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

Why DO all the characters in MK (visually) have the same normals anyway? In a game with traditional graphics they'd have characters with the same moves and similar outfits to save on labor by editing one character to create the other (draw a Ryu sprite then change the head and colors to make it Ken, many such cases). But in MK they weren't drawing anything, they were just filming actors on a blue screen, so they could have had them all do different moves and it wouldn't have been any more work. They threw away visual variety that they could have had for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
The ROM image contains "low level" machine code that is run directly on the CPU. Programmers write in a highly level code, like C (higher level languages you may have heard of are C#, JavaScript, Python, Java, etc., but old school arcade games never used these as they needed to be more optimised for performance) school, which goes through a "compilation" process to turn it into machine code. The code written by the programmer is the source code, and you can't directly extract this from the compiled machine code. Writing in Assembly is as close to machine code as you can get, but even then, there are comments in the file and descriptive names for variables that are lost in the compilation process. Decompilation projects manually review all the compiled code and try to recreate what they think the source code would have looked like before it was compiled. This can be verified, to a degree, by compiling the manually decompiled code and seeing if it matches the ROM, but all the identifier names and any programmer comments cannot be derived from the ROM image.

>>9525592
The way source code functions as a part of the final end product of a finished game, is that all of the human-readable code has been converted into machine language. Operating instructions for the system to perform mathematical instructions and moving memory around. This is the reason why we can't just "crack" the source code out of a game. The Mario 64 decomp devs actually went through every single instruction and deduced their purposes on a larger scale in a ridiculously difficult and drawn out process using emulators and debuggers.

It is NOT easy. Pic is "source" code. You cannot run this through a converter and spit out legible code.

Simply put, compiling takes source code/instructions written by humans, for humans, and translates/compiles it into something made to be interpreted by a machine.
For example, going from something like the C programming language, to potentially an intermediate representation (like assembly or something else), and ultimately always ends up as machine code.
So you have something high level that makes sense to a human like `print("hello")` boil down to many assembly instructions `mov x y; inc a; ...` down to even more machine instructions expressed as binary (usually rendered to humans as hex) `0x07; 0x6F; 0x32 ...`.

Decompiling is that process in reverse, and worse, it's lossy.
Documentation for the code, written as comments in the human readable source, can't be restored since it gets discarded during compilation (the machine doesn't need these, only humans do). Likewise with function and variable names (usually).
You have to read the opcodes for the machine (from the binary file) and try to deduce what could have produced that sequence of operations.
What function(s) could compile into this specific sequence?
Functions plural because multiple high level concepts can compile down to the same instructions, so even if you find an answer, it may not be the original answer.
Almost like an algebra problem, but worse. y + x = 7, what is x and y? 5 and 2? 4 and 3?

The only thing you can really do is get close approximations, and test them. Did my function compile to the same bytes? Does it "match"?

See also: https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2020/05/beyond-emulation-the-massive-effort-to-reverse-engineer-n64-source-code/

Just as with high level languages, you build up and accrue abstractions over time. I mean that both on a personal and project level. You also don't have a lot of the extra bullshit to deal with like an OS or VMM so you can greatly reduce and simplify what you even need to build and deal with in the first place. You write what you want, how you want to , with the only limits being the target machine itself.
Consider something as simple as loading data from a constant address versus making multiple syscalls to deal with some general purpose file system.

When somebody speaks about "source code", they usually mean code coming from a dev that is cleanly written in a way that other humans with programming knowledge can understand, this makes it much more easy to modify for hacks, ports and what not.

Yes, there are tools to partially or completely see the code from a ROM, the problem is said code looks like an unintelligible mess since it doesn't keep any comments or the given names for variables, functions, etc. Some hackers can work with that mess and slowly figure out what is what by trial and error, the end result would be something very close to the official dev source code, but it takes too much time, guess work and autism, and there's still a chance for inaccuracies, therefore, having the official code from a dev is always more convenient than try to reverse engineer it yourself, unfortunately since it has to come from an official source and may be illegal to share, it's very rare for one to come out, so it's a big deal when one does get released. At least if it's from a game people give a shit about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fundamentally different implementation of 3D
Rather than just taking a bunch of triangles that are twisted and turned to make a 3D shape they used something called NURBS. This approach comes from the CAD software that 3D modelling workstations were originally meant to run, and to this day is still used for high-accuracy CAD work.
However as real-time 3D accelerators are meant specifically for polygons those are used in games instead. You'll see a lot of NURBS models used in PS1-era FMVs as those were often made on SGI workstations that were optimized for this kind of workload.

>>9537436
This comment puts it in too simple terms, but basically gets it. The people who were producing basically any kind of visuals that are now considered the peak of "soulful" and "retro" graphics, were just extremely talented and disciplined people working within the limitations of older software/hardware. Retro fags like us who recognize the aesthetic appeal of that time are appreciating all these things in a completely different context. So when modern indie devs go for that look, they can usually recreate the technical limitations and specifics, but lack the top-of-the-line skill and the time-specific mindsets of those eras. An overblown example for comparison would be a modern archeologist trying to recreate ancient egyptian sculpture. He could get the tech down through research, but there's no way to recreate the mindset and education of those ancient artists.

>>9537435
The hell are you talking about? Sounds like you're confusing NURBS with a combination of subdivision modeling and path tracing. NURBS are mostly used for static models in industrial/design settings. All of the 90's/80's CGI videos (such as those posted by the OP) were done with graphics that used normal polygon meshes (usually subdivided), textured and prerendered with pathtracing. You cannot rig and animate an organic, strechable object like a horse or a humanoid with NURBS. You also cannot texture it with much freedom.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think we eventually will but it won't come from any big industry, probably will spring from a savant or team of savants that have to develop their own engine etc. To make it work. A lot goes into it and the mainstream video game industry isn't about to take the time and cost to make that vision a reality when selling mediocrity to people who grew up in a world where mediocrity was not only accepted but celebrated on a global scale makesnmoney hand over fist vs. any attempt at genuine artistry.
Just within those first two webms it occurred to me, for instance, how much of what people see in their heads as "that 90s CG look" has to do with the desaturating effect of being displayed on old analog tech and how VHS and old school video encoding (I'm intuiting that last part and may well be full of shit on that, autists feel free to correct me because the specifics do matter) desaturates the image and that's not inconsequential to the presentation. Were those same clips crystal clear HD I do not think they would be satisfying in the same way. It's not what people picture in their heads, they envision the imperfections as part of the medium.
There's also different forms of it, like that other anon who sounds more knowledgable than me said, this stuff was made using NURBS, and I don't believe that's the same tech as what was used to create the aesthetic of N64 era box art CG, I think all of that style boils down to being rendered on period specific SGI workstation hardware.
I feel like we'll get there by a small group of true blue autists, the kind that truly are mentally set apart to accomplish tasks otherwise infeasible, will make it their goal to either emulate or recreate that technology for the pure sake of preserving the ability to do so, and then a lesser group of passionate individuals will take that work and make games with it. That's my prediction. If not that then I think we will probably reach our tech asymptote pretty soon and it will make the task trivial.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A major reason is because it's pretty ugly and limited. You basically can't create facial expressions unless you're intentionally going for a goofy look. Not on normal characters anyway. Even back in the day, memorable individual characters had to be pretty special to easily emote, like Hexadecimal from Reboot.

There's also the, ya know, over 20 years of traction that 2D pixel art has gained notoriety for since 3D "took its place". People have been making pixel art themselves for a long time and uploading it on the net. There's been a lot of time for people to recognize that your average SNES game looked better than your average PSX game because 3D came too soon. Your average indy developer is a product of this and focused a lot of their free time creative habits on 2D, not 3D.

Also, something else has to be brought up concerning what people have said about talent. The reality is that artists have way less say in how a video game turns out as compared to other people, especially if its a project where you're doing a lot of the development work yourself (using very little frameworks or middleware). The average artist has no idea how to get the weapon effects in Amid Evil to work like they do, and they didn't back in the day, either. The people working on the engine create those kinds of visual effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No self respecting artist wants to intentionally recreate something that looked like complete dog-ass.

Artists want to push boundaries and do the best they can with the available tools. That's what this art style was originally born of- It was the best they could do with the limitations of the time. They were learning as they worked, pioneering into something totally new.

Even if a modern artist wanted to work within the technical limitations of the time, for whatever reason, they still wouldn't recreate something that looks like 90s CG did. They would work differently, they would have access to greater resources, they'd have the accumulated knowledge of 20 years of progress, and they'd make something that looks better.

You are nostalgic for this stuff because it is evocative of a specific period you remembe fondly. But an artist will always strive to create the best they can with their tools. Nostalgia on it's own is a shit reason to make shitty art, so even if you crave that specific flavour of shitty art more than anything, it's likely to stay in it's time. Where it belongs. And where it should be respected.

The data needed wasn't much, but the generated output was into gigabytes, especially if you were doing movies. And it took hours and hours to do 1 frame. CGI in 90s movies took up to a year or more to render on several workstations like that.

>>9539724
>data went into
>gigabytes
I'm not sure what you're really asking when it comes to data in/out, I have never really heard things talked about in those terms. As i explained to you a pure shape doesn't need anywhere near as much data to store the model as would the same shape approximated by many triangles.
If you render a single sphere with one camera and one light (with scanline micropoly OR raytracing) your spatial 'data input' is basically
>sphere position with respect to camera x y z
>light position with respect to camera x y z
>sphere radius
>light direction
like 50 bytes or something, and you might get out a 150MB 8000x8000 .bmp file. If doing scanline, then in between, unseen by you but by the computer, yes a fuckload more memory would be used, but not at once, so you wouldn't need a gigabyte of memory to do it.
But maybe if you wanted to do your sphere real time today with the scanline algorithm, you do need gigabytes to store all the micropoly at once since you don't have time to load and unload the ones to do with different pixel blocks. Hence why UE5 is only just about able to do this today on the ps5 at 2000 lines

That, anon, is ray tracing, especially in the 90s.

> I think even with non-ray traced lighting the aesthetic would still be there, just not as bold.

I get your meaning, and it's true, but to be pedantic remember that ray-tracing literally IS the lighting. You set the light source(s), you set the objects, you set the camera location, and then the rendering engine emits light rays from the light source, off the objects and into the camera, at whatever resolution you've got the RAM and storage for

it's pretty wild the variety of scenes you can construct using the method of rendering, especially considering that the actual geometry files for something like this was probably about 20 kilobytes and the textures not much more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539732
My guy, are you sure? AFAIK, scanline rendering is one of the two options (the other being Z-buffering; they are also combinable) for determining what is visible in 3D scenes - that is: determining what objects are "in front" of other objects, thus rendering them fully, and everything thats "behind" them gets renderred partially.
It has nothing to do with lighting algorithms, which are a different algorithm that can be combined with those that determine visible surface.
Although AFAIK raytracing is an umbrella term and can be used both for visible surface determining and lighting algorithms. The current Nvidia RTX stuff is a hodge-podge of partial raytracing used mostly for reflections that is then upscaled and integrated with other more "classic" realtime techniques.
But I might be wrong about some of this, so someone please correct me...

Montezuma's Return had a bit of that vibe going on, despite it actually being from the 90's. It's all realtime graphics, but it's using all that sweet 3DFX stuff and has great animated lightbaked stuff along with some raytraced 2D sprites which really contribute to the look. It's weird really, since the tech used shouldn't be too far from stuff like Quake, Unreal or Thief and yet the game looks way more like some 90's 3d animation. The goofy stylized stuff helps a lot.

You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

rgb's only necessary if you think it is. composite's ok if you're ok with it. rgb makes the video signal cleaner so you don't get certain video artifacts that you do with composite. some people actually prefer composite because of those artifacts. the only time rgb might be "necessary" is if the console or whatever only outputs rgb (i can't think of any examples of this, maybe there's a computer like this) or if there's some detail you can't make out on composite, which might be discernible on rgb but it could just be that the screen itself can't resolve the detail (because of dot pitch or convergence or what have you).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536724
To properly diagnose this, open the TV up and get a blowdrier. Heat up the big capacitors near the power board until they're about as warm as lukewatm water. If you switch the tv on and it turns on instantly it's definitely bad caps. Any bulging caps are certainly bad. Replace those with caps of the same voltage and capacity (seen as uf or mf commonly.) This isn't a critical problem, but it will slowly add wear and tear to the circuitry if you don't replace caps.

In WWF, the Rockers were a popular tag team that broke up when Shawn Michaels turned heel on his tag team partner Marty Jannetty. A Jannetty is thus the member of a duo or group who has the least success or popularity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
An overenthusiastic employee made a bunch of ridiculously difficult mazes for the game. They used them in the game just because they didn't want to hurt his feelings. Recognizing that the mazes are, in fact, ridiculous, they included a full guide with the game.
You can go through and draw maps of all the dungeons. This is how I like to do it. It's a kind of challenge that doesn't exist in RPGs anymore. For patient people, it's fun.
Or you can skip all that trouble and use the maps that were included with the game. It's still fun, although there is a bit of grinding. I kind of like the grinding.

I've been doing this somewhat regularly for about a decade now. I had a few attempts at a single "game notes" book, but that has never materialized. One had loads of notes in it, but I left that with a previous relationship. One of my fondest memories was making maps of the crazy MOTHER / EarthBound Zero factories. The music in these games really burns into your brain permanently, and shapes how you feel. It is super cool to go back and reference old notes, though, on repeated playthroughs. The first time took forever, but this time it's your own previous hard work which allows you to coast more easily through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: PS2 is my favourite game of all time but you have to enjoy grinding to enjoy it. I fucking love grinding a JRPG party, and I love the difficulty curve of PS2. You are kept perpetually poor, forcing you to work hard to upgrade your party. The ability to configure your party membership throughout the game creates emergent gameplay, like patrolling a small area of the map with a party of 2 to fast level specific party members with specific powers. The difficulty curve makes the minimal story elements all the more satisfying when they're delivered. And the music, aesthetics and atmosphere are just perfect. Its telling that when Sega rebooted Phantasy Star for the Dreamcast, it was the look and feel of PS2 that they sought to translate into 3d

>>9535101
Not sure about bugs, I'm OP and I'm playing the improvement patch. It fixes most of the retarded stuff, like super slow walk speed, screen flashing red several times on every hit, game text being all caps, and so on. The game's script is also updated, some items are renamed to be more consistent with the later games. The game mechanics are all preserved intact, there are just light overhauls to tech learning order here and there, as well as removal of the most obviously useless weapons/items. I guess it's the best option if you want the most vanilla version of the game without the bugs / text errors / irritating stuff. there's an option to turn on double exp / meseta if you want, you'll need to apply a separate patch that comes in the archive.
My only gripe with the patch is that the walk speed is a tiny bit fast for towns, doing precise movement may be a bit hard, but it's way worth saved time.

>>9526658
>it's a fucking labyrinth
Yeah, they are. The way I understand it, you are supposed to beat them in several tries: go in, explore, teleport away, heal, go back.
Or use the guide. The mazes are not that complicated though, except for >>9529090
A couple of gameplay hints:
Grinding become easier halfway through the game when you get a set of armor in the second dam that casts Gra with no TP charge.
Robots and magical enemies tend to resist melee damage. Guns and techs ignore resistance.
All guides tell that Kain's techs work on robots and Hugh's techs work on biomonsters. What they don't tell you is that they both work on magical enemies in the later dungeons.

>Is the original really so buggy?
here's a small sample:
- dialogue text bugs (some lines are accidentally omitted or attributed to the wrong character)
- Laconian Dagger, a weapon bought/found late game, having an attack stat of 4 instead of 40
- Hugh is unable to cast Gires outside of battle
- missing sounds during spellcasting for certain techniques
- contrary to what >>9535364 's tech list states, Shinb was meant to allow a guaranteed escape from battle with biomonsters when cast, but the tech was broken and never worked
- If you choose to DEFEND in battle and then on the next turn use an item or cast a tech, the DEFEND status is maintained, only choosing ATTACK will cause it to drop
- missing animation frames from some enemies in battle

Looked exciting at first, but that style is exact same as modern indie "pixel art". Too much contrast, too shiny and too much shading, emphasizing 3D look way too much, every single detail is embossed. Everything looks like it's made of candy, Kain's back looks like he does steroids.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539613
I used to think so too, even after playing through it once getting all four endings by abusing the save system. The battle system needed work (put all points into healing, none of the other techniques matter because melee combat too strunk), the localization drops massive amounts of story detail that was in the Japanese version, monster design and animations leave a lot to be desired after the phenomenal work in the last two games, and a lot of the towns and dungeons feel very copy-and-paste. Why is there a sunny, grass-filled village in the middle of a terminally snowy dome?

Basically, the game feels very unfinished and lacking polish. That being said, the music is on par with some catchy tunes (not many though) and the Generations system gives the game a little bit of added replay value even if by the red generation everything basically wraps up in the exact same way despite the 2nd generation going to great lengths to pit you on either side of the Orakian-Layan war depending on your choice of bride at the end of the 1st.

There's actually a fun little jrpg to have here if you can get passed some of its quirks. It's a lot more forgiving and less-grindy than PS2, at least.

Close. Stenzek was providing an official Duckstation core, only it was closed-source (which actually violates its GPL license). However, he got into several spats with the libretro team (mostly with Twinaphex, who's similarly caustic) and ended up fucking off and ceased working on the Duckstation core or providing support for it. As a result, they decided to create a fork called Swanstation, and Stenzek went on to make claims about it using "stolen code from his private repo" for which he never provided any proof, and it all came to a head when he found out about a cloud gaming service known as Piepacker that was using Swanstation for PS1 emulation, which was reported to have made a few million in profits, and that it was employing a libretro contributor at the time. He went absolutely nuclear over all this, and he ended up conflating all these things together and made up a narrative that the libretro team was making millions off of his stolen code, and used it as an excuse to cease working on Duckstation altogether, which then pissed off dicksuckers in Reddit, Twitter and Resetera, who promptly attempted to cancel libretro and RetroArch. The effort lasted all of a week, especially once enough people began poking holes in Stenzek's MUH STOLEN CODE narrative and screenshots of his own shit behavior made the rounds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521549

They're zoomer retards, it's that simple, don't try to reason with them.

They think they are "recreating" the "effect" of a CRT screen, but that's not what they are doing, and unless they have a HDR 8K monitor that's barely even possible. Let alone on the garbage 10 year old 1080P panel they probably use them on.

The annoying thing is, filters are not a meme; but the real function is to simply break the image up. That's what a REAL CRT does. It's a form of natural anti-aliasing, it's an optical illusion that tricks your eye into thinking the pixels blend together. If people were making filters that did this without trying to replicate a CRT we would probably have vastly superior filters.

Personally I just use a 50% opaque scanline filter, and increase brightness to compensate, making sure the line integer matches the internal rendering resolution. When I play from sofa distance I can't see the lines, it just looks like a smooth image instead. It's not as perfect as a real CRT but it's better than the eye-strain inducing garbage of "CRT filters".

>>9532823
There are several good ports. My personal favorite way to play is the M2 3D one on the 3ds. They did a phenomenal job and even fish in a given school are at different depths. I have played it emulated many times though with no issue.

I do recommend a guide if you feel stuck, there are two quests near the beginning where you rescue lost dolphins and those give you very useful abilities for the rest of the game.

Finally though, if you find yourself very stuck or the game is too hard, or you just want to play it more casually, all versions including the GBA port have the debug code which is quite robust.

You can yourself invulnerable if you want, level select or teleport to any area of the current zone. Almost more fun though is you can change the music tempo which given Ecco's incredible soundtrack makes for some really cool variations you can do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9532972
Good luck with it, I'm glad to help! It's one of my favorite games of all time, but I understand well why it's always been a little niche. My suggestion if you try again is just take it slow for a while and learn how the game flows. The second level has an octopus that is there to help teach you. You'll feel low on air and like you should be rushing, but the octopus will slap you back of you do. In Ecco, rushing is what usually kills you. Your air is always depleting and you will think you're going to drown if you don't, but success relies on keeping calm under pressure and being accurate. Many people say it's crazy hard, but really outside of the Asterite fight and the Vortex queen at the end, it's really not that difficult ot just takes a kind of mentality that most games don't require as much.

>>9535508
I actually saw it from a totally different perspective, to me it was like "hmmmm never seen this kinda stuff before.."
lets not forget that most of the "sister games" back then were just Barbie crap. back then a Dolphin on the cover did not automatically give people the feeling of it being a kids game, hell the Genesis was even marketed as a console for dudebros way before the xbox360 coined that phrase.
back then most of us just didn't even feel like we could be subjected to kids games on the Genesis, Snes for sure cuz Nintendo. but Genesis just felt differently.
you saw Toejam & Earl and you didn't think "oh kiddy alien game" no you thought "wow, thats a whacky bro experience!"

Even now when I go through my rom collection and find stuff like Richard Scarry's Busytown it feels.. off somehow. as in "this shouldn't be on the Genesis"
That's just how it was marketed, even Lion King and Aladdin didn't feel like they were for kids, they were for all ages.

posts.com:
>>9535820
>It's not something like Space Harrier or Streets of Rage that you can play and even if it kicks your ass, still have fun with the pacing

See I guess I just don't see it that way. While I love Space Harrier to a huge degree, I also like Ecco. They are very different, but I don't see that as a bad thing. I hate this comparison being thrown around, but in many ways Ecco is like Demon's Souls was compared to other contemporary games.

From an objective standpoint there are many harder retro games, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania 3, Super Ghouls n Ghosts, Battletoads, 1ccing Gradius etc (all of which get regular threads here by people declaring that the difficulty is overstated) are all much harder than anything Ecco throws at you, even the last levels. Most games, especially platformers have similar enough controls that you tangentially get good at others while playing it. With Ecco, nothing else plays like it so you're also learning a whole new control scheme.

However, all those games have a similar flow which is much more action focused. Ecco is all about being careful, scoping out the environment with your sonar and clearing an area of enemies so when you have to rush through you can. It's very different from many other console games of the era, but I don't see that as a bad thing.

>>9536263
It's really not a handwave, it's how the game is designed. You can call it tedious, but it was never meant to be a bing bing wahoo rush to the finish type game. Unreliable just makes no sense, if you want to permakill an enemy, you can. It's about making the decision you want to.

Again as I always say in these threads, since first playing Ecco has always been in my top selection of games and I almost always have a playthrough on the go somewhere. Along with that love is the understanding it doesn't appeal to everyone, but I don't see that as a bad thing. Games should appeal to many different people.

>>9536882
>SMB had worse jumping than Mega Man and fucking elevator physics
As someone who's programmed a Mega Man engine (studied the physics and replicated it all), I love the games but can't agree with this. Mega Man's physics are very basic. You might prefer them because you like having more control after jumping, but there's zero momentum and I think they're much less interesting for platforming.

It works well for Mega Man which emphasizes shooting as much as jumping, but it would be boring for a more pure platformer like Mario.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In their context, when originally released, SMB3 was a better game. It was late in the NES life and was the crowning achievement of the console. It had horizontal and vertical scrolling (don't take that for granted), a huge number of levels and tilesets, a bunch of powers and upgrades, a diverse world, etc. In comparison, the base game of SMW is inferior.

However, currently, SMW is a better game due to rom hacks and kaizos. SMW does have far better movement than SMB3 and is a much better foundational "base" for hacks and mods.

SMB3 should've had tighter movement and fewer autoscrollers (way too damn many). SMW should've had better levels, but that's fixed with modern kaizos.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536932
This is correct.

Look, I loved Mega Man when I owned an NES growing up. I had MM2-6 and played the shit out of them.

Unfortunately, I totally agree that the movement is barebones and basic. Mega Man turns on a dime and there's no acceleration or momentum. His horizontal movement is instant with no ramp-up. I think he even rises and falls vertically at a constant rate.

>>9538989
not that anon but it's pretty obvious. 3 has tons of levels but they're all 5 seconds long, so that the map feature will work as intended. NES games were famously strapped for content due to all the restrictions of the era, having a game where you could willingly skip tons of the levels in various ways meant that each one needed to be bite-sized so it wouldn't impact things too much on either end. but that wound up creating a negative experience in the end since by the time you get into the groove of playing the level will already be over, just as that anon said.

world was properly able to flesh out the idea of a map and tons of optional levels due to the console it was on, but unfortunately was rushed as mentioned above. both have many compromises for their respective systems.

https://yewtu.be/watch?v=LC_KKxAuLQw
The Wii was gimmicky, but in 2010, this guy used the wii sensor bar, put it on his head and flipped it around to make this tech demo. I remember my jaw hitting the floor when I first saw it. That's when I knew that true VR games were going to be a reality. Today, I'm a simdad with a VR cockpit and games like iRacing and Il-2 are amazing. As the tech becomes cheaper and more readily available to the average consumer, VR gaming is going to explode.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have made several retro Windows PCs.

You want period accurate-ish. Slow is good, there are a ton of games that are speed sensitive and it's much easier to get things working and compatible with a good 90s motherboard chipset than "the highest end." That said you can use more modern parts when it makes sense and it's nice to replace hard dicks with SD cards or SSDs.

My fav setups that I've put together are probably
1) a 440bx motherboard with a 1ghz Pentium 3, a voodoo 3, and an ISA OPL3 soundcard
2) a super socket 7 with a K6-III, an nvidia FX5500 PCI, and an ISA OPL3 soundcard connected to an MT-32 & SC-88
3) a socket A mobo with an Athlon XP 2600+, an nvidia FX5700 Ultra, and an Yamaha XG YMF754-R PCI connected to a Yamaha MU90

They all run Win98 and I use them for different eras & kinds of games.

There are a ton of great options though, I also really like the late 2000s era thin-clients I've set up to use Windows & DOS, and shout out to vintage Macs -- a Power Mac G3 is a lot of fun.

>>9535015
>32 bit versions of Windows support 4GB, except that is also limited by GPU, so if you have 4GB of RAM and a 512MB graphics card, you'll be limited to 3.5GB of system RAM.
This has never been true about any Windows OS. You are limited to 3.5 GB of RAM on WinXP 32-bit since that's the most RAM it can address. Go ahead and run a WinXP machine with 4GB's of RAM and a 64MB video card, it will still only recognize 3.5GB.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538020
Yeah, I have a Windows XP rig with a 4GB GPU, it still recognises about 3.5GB RAM

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538020
That's a motherboard thing. By default, old motherboards would reserve 512MB of memory for graphics, audio, ethernet, etc and prevent the operating system from touching that RAM. The problem the motherboard is trying to prevent is OS dependent, meaning older operating systems will create problems if the motherboard doesn't withhold memory at around the 4GB limit. WinXP is not one of these operating systems, it doesn't need reserved memory withheld from it, it won't create problems if you just give it 4GB. If your motherboard has Memory Hole Remapping, turn that on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536235
He attacks strictly based on your position: an overhead stab if you're close to either edge of the boat, and an outward swipe if you're near the middle. What I like doing is baiting the overhead, running (not dashing because you might fall) to the other side, then shooting Flame into his face. Repeat several times.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536235
Use the fixed shot mode (white suit) and the Flame weapon. Crouch, and then use diagonals to move the boat to the sides so you can dash to dodge his attacks. After dodging, shoot the Flame upwards towards the lobster while still crouching. This method makes the fight much easier.

>>9523840

Games should be categorized based on the types of technology used, not arbitrary release dates. Look at the way architecture is categorized for example (Classical, Mid-century modern, Postmodern, Neomodern, New Classical, Contemporary, etc…). Mid century modern will never become classical. Similarly, Jazz music will never become classical. Its dumb to call an 8 bit hand held a later gen just because it came out later. The gamegear is literally just a master system. The Wii is literally just an overclocked gamecube and has a weaker CPU & GPU than the Xbox. Using this logic, here's the REAL gaming eras:

Pre-Retro Era:
Gen 1 - Literally just Pong
Gen 2 - Atari 26/52/78, Vectrex, shitboxes nobody cares about

[Insert Gaming Crash Here]

Retro Era AKA The Golden Age:
Gen 3 (8 Bit) - NES, Gameboy, Gameboy Color, Master System, Game Gear, PC 88, MSX, ZX Spectrum, Pico-8, TIC-80
Gen 4 (16 bit) - SNES, GBA, Genesis, PC98, TG16, Amiga, Neo Geo
Gen 4.5 - Sega 32X, 3DO, PC-FX
Gen 5 (32 bit 2D + Low Poly 3D) - PS1, Saturn, N64, DS
Gen 5.5 - Dreamcast, PSP, 3DS
Gen 6 (Mid Poly) - PS2, Gamecube, Wii

[Insert Globohomo Here]

Modern Era (HD widescreen, Microtransactions, Day 1 patches, hyper realism, Casualization, homogenized controllers, homogenized architecture, mocap, facescan, Californian management, etc...):
Gen 6.5 (High Poly, 480p-ish) - Xbox, Vita
Gen 7 (Mainly 720p) - 360, PS3, Wii U,
Gen 7.5 - Switch
Gen 8 (Gen 7 + Stable 1080p) - PS4, Xbone
Gen 8.5 (Gen 7 + 4K) - PS4 Pro, Xbone X
Gen 9 (Gen 7 + 4K + RTX) - PS5, Xbox SX

Not that anon, but I think you just complicated shit due to your uncontrollable autism. Retro derived from the word retrograde, which means to move backwards. the definition of retro consists of mimicry or imitation of a past decade, not having the petina of a bygone era. Though, as language be it the way it do, the common consensus of retro is broad and largely vague. Which is why everyone here squabbles like nomenclature legislatures about what “retro videogames” means. Quite literally, retro videogames are games that emulate or imitate games from previous decades. You can argue and categorize as many excel spreadsheets as you want, but that’s the factual definition of retro videogames. Trying to move shit around in generational categorization, is retarded. You completely break the foundation of what generation means by doing so.

posts.com:
My recommendations for order play through and platform.

1. RE 96 or Directors cut (non-dual shock) PS1 on CRT
2. RE2 '98 PS1 or DC on CRT
3 RE3 '99 PS1 or DC on CRT
4. CODE VERONICA X (GCN or "PS2 Classic" version on PS4, stay away from the PS2 version and the HD MT Framework versions)
5. REmake PC or GCN + CRT
6. RE0 PC or GCN + CRT
7. Biohazard Outbreak Files 1+2 w/English patch on pscx2 with online via the outbreak resurrection server
8. RE4 PC + HD mod or GCN on CRT
9. RE5 GOLD PC
10. Revelations 1+2 PC
11. RE6 PC
12. RE7 GOLD PC
14. RE8 GOLD PC

Gits and shiggles if you really enjoy the series:
Umbrella Chronicles/Darkside Chronicles on Wii/Dolphin, Gun Survivor 2 w/ light gun or mouse

If you are a completionist:
RE Gaiden GBC and Gun Survivor JPN w/ lightgun

Symphony of the Night doesn't use Redbook audio for the music. It's compressed ADPCM streams that has about a 4:1 compression ratio. Yes it does still take up a bulk of the space, but it's already compressed because there's a ton of it.

Just because a game is on a CD based system doesn't mean it's always using Redbook audio.

It's not a difficult skill to teach yourself in adulthood. The tools and materials don't have to be expensive either.
Just don't be like countertop faggot and buy a desoldering gun before a fucking multimeter. What a dumb cunt.
- Soldering iron
- Solder
- Flux
- Some kind of fan for blowing or sucking up fumes
- Some low-gauge wire for bodging
- Multimeter
- Side cutters
That's basically all you need for basic troubleshooting and repair. If you get really into it you can go for an oscilloscope, a desoldering tool, and whatever other expensive items.

>>9519535
I did get a desoldering pump, it was included with the soldering station as well as the solder itself. It's a 60/40 solder which I understand is the most common one. At this point, I would worry to much about the type of solder, the one you buy at the hardware store is going to be just fine, but if you must know, there is a type of solder material that includes flux inside the solder tube. From what I understand, you really want to get some flux so that you can break the oxidation surface in most metallic components and the solder sticks to it properly. I think that is more important.
And as far as removing solder goes, I'm going to use a desoldering pump, but you may also you those desoldering copper braids.

>>9523926
Took forever. Lots of fucking around with one of those dogshit solder suckers and wick. But there were still a few pins that connect to a large ground plain that I just couldnt get free.

I ended up getting it out with a fucking heat gun. I put the board chip-side down against an iron 45lb plate with the PPU over the center hole. I covered the motherboard with several layers of aluminum foil so that only the PPU pins were exposed. Then I heater it up a bit at a time and started tuggging on the PPU from the bottom underneath the iron plate until eventually I tugged it free

I was so scared that I probably just fried the chip... but it worked. Still going strong to this day

Where the battery connects? Yes, between those two, as well as from one pad of the battery to just about anywhere else. I wiped down the board with alcohol last night, as well as the connectors on the N64 itself, and just tested it again. No difference, game works as usual, but no data stays saved. I don't know if power is completely cut to the cartridge memory when the "Reset" button on the console is used, but using that instead of On/Off still led to memory being erased.
From further reading, the only two things I've discovered are:
1) multiple people in similar situations who said they had broken pin/trace connections to the chips, so they soldered wires directly from whichever pin(s) were disconnected to the appropriate chip. I'd have to spend a lot of time continuity testing and then finding a wire to put on there, which is more work than I'm willing to do, or;
2) I also saw a post from a guy saying that he owns two N64s, and one of them wipes the game data from cartridges he uses with it. If my problem is with the N64, that's possibly another can of worms, and would very likely be the same approach/solution as above. The only other game I have to test with is Mario Kart 64, which holds its data no problem. I don't think it utilizes the same CR2032 battery-based save system / PCB model, so I'm not sure if an N64-based fault would necessarily lead to data wiping on it anyway.

posts.com:
>>9519589
>How do you solder these little fuckers?
one leg at a time. the other responses are fucking with you.
put solder+iron on a pad, slide the component into place (this is called 'tacking it down'), remove iron, solder the other side, and then clean up the first side if nits messy.
>Also how do you extract components without fucking up the solder pads
Use heat, not force. If you use force, shit breaks. Stuff will move with basically zero pressure when it's done right.
The exact method depends on the component (SMD vs TFT, simple two-leg devices vs complex multi-leg devices, etc) but for through-hole stuff you just remove all the solder using a good sucker or braid, gently moving the legs as you do so, and components will fall right out.
for small two-contact SMD stuff, you can usually just use lots of solder and a big tip to heat both sides at the same time and slide them off. components may get damaged due to heat when you do this, but the pads will be fine.
>(and if you do how easy is it to repair)?
Not easy. It's not an "experts-only" skill but it's tedious and not for beginners. practice on shit you dont care about because you WILL cause more damage than you fix the first few times you do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Many. More people today appreciate Roguelike games than back when Rogue first came out, including retro ones like ADoM. I remember when SimCity 4 first came out, many people complained it was overly difficult to maintain a city and not as enjoyable as 2000 or 3000, now people consider it to be the best in the series. E.T. on the 2600 was considered absolute garbage at the time, now people have read the manual and understand how to play the game it's not considered so bad. Friday the 13th on NES also got left in the weeds, now people consider it a somewhat flawed action game. Starcraft Brood War has more balanced maps, more freedom in map creation, and far more UMS custom maps to play on than it ever has, along with less bugs than it did in the retro days.
Add in mods and hacks, and tens of thousands of retro games can be made better than they ever were. Saving in games that used to use passwords, mods that remove slowdown, mods that fix graphical and text issues, mods that fix bugs and glitches, and so on. Retro videogames are getting better by the day to the point even crappy games like Super Pitfall are getting overhauled into something halfway decent.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9530078
>I honestly don't know what appeals to so many people about this kind of back and forth game design.
Maximum player agency. The game has faith in the player not giving up on it, which makes the world feel very different than one whose highest priority is to stop players from quitting (most modern interpretations). It helps the believability of the setting.

>I feel like Metroid design is a relic from the original hardware limitations and has no other redeeming qualities.

You should probably not assume game design that differs from your preference is a result of hardware limitations if you can help it. It's as silly as the people that claim turn based games only exist because real time combat wasn't possible (there have always been real time games).

>>9530062
Jap was used as a slur in the US in older times, based in the US fighting against Imperial Japan in WW2, fueled by the people who where actually there and fought in the Pacific, those who actually saw the atrocities and crimes of Imperial Japan, as well as those we knew the people who did, those who lost someone in that fighting, and the overall propaganda from the time.

There was also Japanese export goods in the 1950s and 1960s, which to a very large degree was low quality ripoff crap of little value (mind, much of Japan was bombed to pieces in the war, and there was still rebuilding and recovering), combine that with old war animosity and people paint their pictures. Come the 1970s and 1980s, Japan would increasingly start exporting instruments and consumer electronics of actually decent and good quality, so together with better received exports and younger generations who didn't have the closer perception of the war, some of this fades. Of course, there was also a perception of Japanese industry as a serious competitive threat to American industry in the 1980s, so there was some paranoia around that, but then said industry faces some economical hardships in the 1990s.

Overall, "Jap" as a slur for the Japanese is indeed a thing in the US, but it's a faded thing from older times which you don't see in younger generations. Millennials have this idea of it from their older relatives (such as an older relative using phrasing like "Getting Jap'd.", compare to getting "Getting Gyp'd.", but American zoomers have very little conception about its use as a slur, most won't think twice and just hear and use it as a shorthand for Japanese, unaware of any offensive connotations. Of course, if the word stops being used with offensive intent, it stops being offensive.

Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

I love my CRT, but even I admit that we're getting VERY close to the full obsolescence of CRTs. OLED motion clarity at 240hz is nearly identical, and input lag has come down to 4ms — that's far more appealing than the 1-16ms of variable input lag you'll get on a CRT. Video scalers with genuine hardware represents our last step towards the final goal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524408
Unfortunately, it's not easily obtainable knowledge, you should know C, you should understand how the compilator processes your code and you should understand the assembly language of a target platform(MIPS in the case of PSX). Tools allow you to decompile an executable file to asm functions with generic names, even convert them to c. But it's not like load exe to Ghidra and getting a working code.

In rare cases, devs forgot the symbol file on a disk so you can obtain names for functions and variables but usually, they don't. So you need to guess names for thousands of functions and variables.

Reverse engineering is a hobby for a high skilled and autistic programmers.

When my friend had his first kid, I told him "congratulations", and he responded "thanks buddy... guess I'll see you in 10 years". Since his kid was born 3 years ago, I can count the number of times I've seen him on one hand. What's really sad is that it's unlikely to get better. I wasted a total of 4 years with my ex wife, then I had to recover from the divorce, then get out dating again. Even if my gf and I got married and had a kid by this time next year (unlikely), there would still be a significant age gap (5+ years) between my kid and most of my friends' kids. A lot of parents, most of my friends included, keep in touch by organizing "play dates" with kids of similar age, but my kids wouldn't really be able to play with the others because they would be at different development stages. So I feel increasingly shut-out of this once-close circle of friends. Feels bad man.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9526446
Animation, sound, art design, level design/variety are all top-notch. Boss design is great and plenty of enemy variety. Primary and secondary weapons are well-balanced and there is a trade-off between more firepower vs. higher rank.

What I really love though is the slower, more deliberate approach to the game. I think that's what a lot of people struggle with, this is a game where you are really meant to proceed with caution and really take advantage of the fact that the game doesn't autoscroll. Every time you play, you get a bit more efficiency, a bit better method to approach a section, and can better parse the vast amount of information that is thrown at you at once. And then when you start to get really good, you can do speed strats (unfortunately there is no scoring incentive, but still fun). It's definitely a game that grows on you.

The game itself is not really that slow, especially when you know what you're doing. If you mean slowdown, yeah it is pretty bad (just like the Metal Slug games), but you can remove it through emulation and the game is massively improved.

The rank system is kinda fucked though; the game is actually easier if you don't pick up all the powerups. You need to make the decision between rushing past sections or going slow and thorough. When you learn the game, you can do sections very quickly and pointblanking shreds bosses.

Just like with the Slug games, turbo + removing slowdown makes the game so much better. With turbo you can also pointblank the last boss and it dies way faster (he also has less health with lower rank from not picking up as many powerups). I'm not sure what other problems you are having with the last level, it's just all about routing and figuring out how best to approach each section consistently (like any good shmup/run-n-gun)

In terms of 1CC or 1LC, In the Hunt is probably actually easier than even like Slug 1, it's just a more rough learning curve.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526418
From a casual perspective, it has great artwork and sprites....but the game isn't that fun. And games THRIVE based on the casual player.

From a casual player's perspective:

You are getting by enemies from above AND below (no room to breathe). Your area of movement is limited to a narrow section of water (assuming the stage isn't in the way). The stage constantly shifts and shoots out random rocks or coral reef to block or kill you. And worst of all the game treats your submarine's main weapon, the TORPEDO, like a normal bullet. It doesn't feel satisfying to hit an enemy with a big torpedo only for them to shrug it off. Then you gotta fire 5 or 10 more torpedos just to kill them. That's not how submarine warfare should be or feel. The whole thing feels stiff.

If I saw this in 1993 at the arcades (I might have), I wouldn't play it more than a handful of times and never try it again. And based on what I saw, In the Hunt wasn't that popular at arcades. Not like later games of the 90s.


Like other anon said, the submarine levels in Metal Slug were much more well done, and approachable. It embraced the wackiness of the level without going overboard. You could hop in and out of a submarine as a diver and still shoot enemies. You could shoot bullets from your submarine (yes I know it's not possible in real subs, but I accept that for fun gameplay). You could move around in a larger area. And lastly your torpedoes actually matter. They have big power behind them. Metal Slug just got everything just right in gameplay and design.

In the Hunt feels like an earlier version of Metal Slug's submarine levels. An early version where things aren't properly fine tuned or correctly balanced. Like an early draft. But it has great artwork and sprites though.

I can see why hardcore schmup fans like In the Hunt, but I don't enjoy it as a casual player. And if I don't enjoy it, then I won't replay it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539243
You have to use the green and blue missiles to one-shot enemies, the red is more for rapid-fire. There are tons of times where you peek out, pop a depth charge or missile and then slink away, it's pretty great. For damage output though, generally you want to pointblank with your depth charges or balloons.

The main issue is just the rank system. The game is much more fun and more manageable at lower ranks, but casual players are just going to pick up every powerup. I do also think it could benefit from a slightly faster movement speed. I think slower movement speed is great for the type of gameplay it rewards, but it could be just like 10-20% faster.

Metal Slug's submarine stages are just way too basic in comparison. I never found them that fun, and having to move towards enemies to fire at them is just a bit janky.

>>9518542
>>9518605
Decompiling is a pain, and usually, you will need to sort out a lot of things by yourself.
Even if decompilers now can separate code from data (which is helped in consoles starting at PS1 gen because some sort of memory formatting was common) you will likely end up with assembly with variable and functions name meaning nothing.
Well, at least, I tried it for the game boy, and so it was.
I don't see why PS1 would be different (except maybe if they let the debug symbols on the final CD? That's not unheard of, but quite rare).

Anyways, good luck, and enjoy your project!
It you can post your advancements here, that would be really great.

What game do you want to decompile?

>https://tetracorp.github.io/tokimeki-memorial/methods/decompiling-psx-games.html
>https://www.reddit.com/r/REGames/comments/lkbzei/how_to_get_started_decompiling_psx_games/ (I know, Reddit, but, hey, this is sensible for once.)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9520325
The Jetsons Invasion of the Planet Pirates comes to mind.
As a licensed game developed by Taito for the SNES, they re-used the game engine and level designs for another licensed game in Japan; Youkai Buster: Ruka no Daibouken.

The game is mostly the same, but the key differences aside from the change in characters and visuals, is a different intro cutscene, the introduction of bonus levels after each action level's boss fight, a whole new final boss, and the inclusion of additional cheat codes whilst the game is paused. The game is however two levels shorter, not all levels were converted from the original game, but some mini-game segments were put in their place.

Whichever version you play though, it is a genuinely good game, nothing amazing, but worth a play.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9531151
First, take a crash course in electronics circuits.
Then, build a transiver from 5V to 3.3V.
I think the best way to do it would be to use an ESP32 with WiFi.
Then, code some kind of API (check if extension is present, init, get access point list, connect to one, send a request, receive an answer, etc.
Then, code the software (and if you ant it to be useful, think of it as a project using a lib. Like, don't do some URL check or whatever in the game code.)
Lastly, enjoy!
I would start super simple with a game that just check if the extension is plugged.
An other on that does that and list the networks and their strength.
Lastly, one that goes and fetch a text file somewhere on the internet.

As for the hardware, I don't know what buses the NES have exposed. Maybe the same as cartridges? If so, you are midly fucked. You expansion may present as a RAM page, where you write at some addresses, and it gives you answers at other addresses?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9532426
>Are there any NES games that make use of the "illegal opcodes" I hear exist in the 6502?
"Games using unofficial opcodes

The use of unofficial opcodes is rare in NES games. It appears to occur mostly in late or unlicensed titles:

Beauty and the Beast (E) (1994) uses $80 (a 2-byte NOP).[2]
Disney's Aladdin (E) (December 1994) uses $07 (SLO). This is Virgin's port of the Game Boy game, itself a port of the Genesis game, not any of the pirate originals.
Dynowarz: Destruction of Spondylus (April 1990) uses 1-byte NOPs $DA and $FA on the first level when your dino throws his fist.
F-117A Stealth Fighter uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Gaau Hok Gwong Cheung (Ch) uses $8B (XAA immediate) as a 2-byte NOP. The game malfunctions after selecting Left from the main menu if that instruction is not emulated.
Infiltrator uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Puzznic (all regions) (US release November 1990) uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Super Cars (U) (February 1991) uses $B3 (LAX).

Homebrew games

The MUSE music engine, used in Driar and STREEMERZ: Super Strength Emergency Squad Zeta, uses $8F (SAX), $B3 (LAX), and $CB (AXS).[3]
Attribute Zone uses $0B (ANC), $2F (RLA), $4B (ALR), $A7 (LAX), $B3 (LAX), $CB (AXS), $D3 (DCP) and $DB (DCP).
The port of Zork to the Famicom uses a few unofficial opcodes."
From: https://www.nesdev.org/wiki/CPU_unofficial_opcodes
